Foreword Data analytics: European Wheel of Competitiveness 3 Foreword Competitiveness is underlying the priorities set by the President Junker for his mandate. Competitive economies allow high and sustainable growth to benefit the wellbeing of citizens. High-quality official statistics play a fundamental role for the assessment of the performance of European economies, enable to identify potential reform areas and to design and properly implement the reforms. The European Wheel of Competitiveness (EWoC) is the fruit of a close collaboration between Eurostat and the Joint Research Centre together with European Commission services working in the area of competitiveness analysis. It attempts to put together key data on the different aspects of competitiveness, going beyond its purely economic dimension. It is aimed at supporting competitiveness analysts in EU institutions or in Member States, but it is also relevant to others active in the field of competitiveness, in think tanks or academia. This paper is meant to be more than a mere statistical analysis: its ambition is to serve as a quality check of the EWoC design. The aim is to produce similar analyses prior to the launch of future projects or initiatives. It provides also evidence how inter-service collaboration, between Eurostat and the Joint Research Centre, can improve the quality of the results by reaping the benefits of bringing together statisticians and data scientists. Abstract Data analytics: European Wheel of Competitiveness 4 Abstract This study aims to realize a statistical analysis of competitiveness in the EU-28 based on a statistical reference framework, previously defined as the European Wheel of Competitiveness. This framework comprises a list of 35 indicators (EWoC indicators) related to macroeconomics, microeconomics, globalization, environment and socio-institutional aspects. The analytical methods for this study were established in line with the Statistical reference framework for competitiveness analysis in the EU-28 Member States(1). As a rather broad concept, competitiveness can be described by a large set of different factors and definitions. The aim of this analysis is to show possible redundancy between indicators, but also possible explanatory power. Moreover, it tests the initial assumption that the largest principal components will be sufficient to explain the variability in the observed dataset. Finally, it detects possible patterns based on available set of indicators. Results confirmed some well-known correlations. For instance, the unemployment rate is positively correlated with the indicator People at risk of poverty or social exclusion (AROPE) , which is also negatively correlated with the Real GDP per capita. Nevertheless, the performed correlation analysis did not provide any substantial results regarding some other expected correlations. It has to be mentioned at this point that, the presence or the absence of correlation results between several indicators of the set of EWoC indicators, is a fact that should not be understand as a weakness of the EWoC framework but rather as a strength due to the fact that there is not redundant information. Exploring the high correlations between the aforementioned indicators and indicators by themselves, it was decided to control for the indicator 4. Concerning the results obtained with partial correlation analysis, it was evident that most of the previously captured correlation actually comes from the Gross domestic expenditure on R&D. More precisely, when controlling the correlation for the aforementioned indicator, the correlation across EWoC indicators becomes weaker or insignificant in almost all cases. For that reason, and other reasons detailed in the article, indicator 4 was not used for the latter analysis. Finally, the correlation analysis showed that indicator 34: Control of corruption could be also removed from the set of the EWoC indicators. The cross-correlation analysis explored time series correlation and showed that for the same pair of indicators, different or opposite correlation results can be obtained. This proved that countries may react differently and in several periods in time, to similar economic changes. This result provided the idea of countries clustering. In addition, obtained correlation coefficients vary from country to country. Therefore, it was of interest to look for the evidence of formation of groups of countries. In another words, the country-clusters. EU-28The performed analysis showed that the “big old” EU Member States (France, Germany, United Kingdom, Italy...) form a cluster while the Eastern EU countries, i.e. “newest” Member States (Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Bulgaria, Romania, Croatia...) form a separate cluster. It is also noteworthy the fact that Luxembourg stands out as being very different, insofar as it forms its own cluster (Figure 1). The explored dataset consists of 29 indicators for time span 2000-2014. Therefore, it seemed logic to examine opportunities for the reduction of dimensionality or indicators` grouping. All analysis (Principal Components, k-means cluster analysis and Gaussian mixture model and the Hierarchical agglomerative clustering analysis) showed that indicators, either as a component of one linear combination or as a member of one group, can be classified into 4 groups. It is noteworthy the fact that indicator 29: Real GDP per capita stands out as being different, insofar as it forms its own cluster. ( 1 ) Letizia Montinari, Soeren Lindner, Antonio F. Introduction 1 Data analytics: European Wheel of Competitiveness 9 This study provides a summary of the results( 4 ) of the statistical analysis of indicators of the European Wheel of Competitiveness using real EU-28 Member States data for period 2000-2014. The analytical methods for this study were established in line with the Statistical reference framework for competitiveness analysis in the EU-28 Member States ( 5 ) . As indicated in the aforementioned document, as a rather broad concept, competitiveness can be described by a large set of different factors and definitions. The aim of this analysis is to show possible redundancy between indicators, but also possible explanatory power. Moreover, it tests the initial assumption that the largest principal components will be sufficient to explain the variability in the observed dataset. Finally, it detects possible patterns based on available set of indicators. In line with the aforementioned analytical plan, this article starts with a data exploration phase which includes different correlation analysis (simple, partial and correlation for each dimension of competitiveness – subset of indicators listed at page 7. Correlation analysis is followed by the Cluster analysis (further in text – CA) of EU-28 Member States, as well including the examination of time series patterns. Then, a dimension reduction analysis is conducted, i.e. Principal Component Analysis (further in text – PCA) for each country group (and all EU-28 Member States) obtained under the PCA. Finally, different PCA are tested, in order to validate and reinforce the results. 1.1. Data and methods For the purpose of the multivariate statistical analysis of the set of EWoC indicators, a real EU-28 data for period 2000-2014 was used. Regarding the data sources, several official web-sites were used for the data collection – Eurostat, JRC, OECD and World Bank. Moreover, some indicators required statistical manipulations: for instance, indicator 32: Healthy life years at birth, by sex is summarised as a simple average of value for men and value for women for the same year. Although available, some indicators (e.g. indicator 8: Share of high-growth enterprises ) were excluded from the analysis due to big proportions of missing values. In addition, at the time when data was extracted, data was missing for indicators 18: Share of domestic value added generated in one country by the EU exports of all MS to the rest of the world , 21: Share of service value added content of EU exports of manufacturing goods , 24: Real unit energy cost and 26: Energy intensity by industry . Finally, 30 indicators and 28 countries were examined, in total. However, indicator 4: Gross domestic expenditure on R&D was used only for the Correlation analysis. For the latter analysis it was excluded from the initial dataset. Concerning the data quality, it is noteworthy to mention that data has missing values (more or less, depending on the indicator). Therefore, since some analysis are more sensitive on missing data, results must be taken with caution. For all analysis the statistical software SAS and/or Matlab are used. In addition, it was chosen the 95% or the 99% confidence interval ( α =0.05 or α =0.01). ( 4 ) The results shown in this article are related to the data extracted in September 2016. The authors are not responsible for any further changes in the data when using this article in the future. ( 5 ) European Commission - DG Joint Research Centre, 2016. Introduction

Correlation analysis This section aims to explore different linkages between indicators of the European Wheel of Competitiveness. Correlation analysis is useful because it can indicate a predictive relationship that can be exploited in practice. Nevertheless, this analysis did not go into possible causal relationships among them. 2.1.1. Simple correlation The most familiar measure of dependence between two variables is the Pearson's correlation coefficient 8 . If the variables are independent, Pearson's correlation coefficient is 0, but the converse is not true because the correlation coefficient detects only linear dependencies between two variables. More precisely, this coefficient measures the linear co-movement between pairs of variables giving a value between 1 and − 1 inclusive, where 1 is total positive linear correlation, 0 is no linear correlation, and − 1 is total negative linear correlation. The analysis first started with the exploration of the simple relations between the observed indicators using so- called simple correlation, where the evidence of well-known( 9 ) correlations is searched. Moreover, some other interesting relationships between indicators were observed . Table 1 displays significant correlations between indicators of the European Wheel of Competitiveness taking into account all EU-28 Member States( 10 ). Strong positive correlation (more precisely 0.987 ) was found between indicator 4: Gross domestic expenditure on R&D and indicator 10: R&D expenditure in the business sector (% of GDP). In addition, analysis showed that indicator 33: Government Effectiveness is strongly positively associated with indicator 34: Control of corruption ( 0.945 ). Figures 2 and 4 show the correlation results, in form of a scatter plot, for Gross domestic expenditure on R&D and R&D expenditure in the business sector and correlation results for Government Effectiveness and Control of corruption , respectively. The same figures show the strength and direction of correlation, taking into account all EU-28 Member States. ( 8 ) Pearson`s correlation coefficient (or simply correlation coefficient) is sensitive only to a linear relationship between two variables (which may exist even if one is a nonlinear function of the other). Other correlation coefficients have been developed to be more robust than the Pearson correlation – that is, more sensitive to nonlinear relationships. Partial correlation for the indicator Gross domestic expenditure on R&D The partial correlation analysis, the same as simple, aims to measure the degree of association between two variables. However, in partial correlation, the effect of a controlling variable(s) is removed. In first instance, the linear correlation between many indicators was apparently significant and moderate or high. These findings did not go in a line with the initial hypothesis that each indicator brings some unique information regarding competitiveness. Exploring the high correlations between aforementioned indicators , it was decided to repeat the correlation analysis but this time controlling it for the indicator 4: Gross domestic expenditure on R&D and compare the results. To demonstrate the decision, a selection of empirical evidence and arguments is presented, using both the results from the previous analysis and the definitions of the listed indicators. Cross-Correlation analysis by dimensions of competitiveness Taking into account the results of the correlation analysis, it was also examined how the leading indicator is linked with other indicators in its own dimension of competitiveness. In another words, the cross-correlation analysis was done for each group of indicators by selecting one representative indicator for each dimension — Macroeconomic, Microeconomic, Globalization, Environment and Socio-institutional. 2.1.3.1. MACROECONOMIC INDICATORS The ability of a country to raise its level of income and growth is typically measured by the evolution over time of its real gross domestic product. However, it is very important the way in which countries use the input factors. Having that in mind, in the group of macroeconomic indicators (listed in the introduction), indicator 5: Real labour productivity per hour worked (Sustainable Development Indicator), was selected as representative for its group. Since the analysis showed lack of significant correlation both with indicator I1: Real GDP growth rate (1 year % change) and with indicator I7: Gross fixed capital formation at market prices (% GDP) , the relative results will not be presented. In contrast, as shown in Figure 7, interesting cross-correlation results were found with indicator I2: Unemployment rate (3 year average) in different EU-28 Member States (red highlights the most relevant results). Similar results for each EU-28 Member State can be found in Annex ( Figure 7a ) (grey represent not very meaningful results). Let us recall the fact that the presented correlation results refer, in most cases, to the presence of correlation between several pair of indicators, but the presence or the absence of correlation should be taken as it is and not to be associated as positive or negative. Hierarchical agglomerative clustering analysis Hierarchical clustering is a widely used data analysis tool that allows to build a binary tree of the data that successively merges similar groups of points( 26 ). Visualizing this tree provides a useful summary of the data. The hierarchical agglomerative clustering analysis is a "bottom up" approach: each observation starts in its own cluster, and pairs of clusters are merged as one moves up the hierarchy. In order to decide which clusters should be combined, a measure of dissimilarity between sets of observations is required. In most methods of hierarchical clustering, this is achieved by use of an appropriate metric (a measure of distance between pairs of observations), and a linkage criterion which specifies the dissimilarity of sets as a function of the pairwise distances of observations in the sets. The Mahalanobis distance has been used, which implies the calculation of the covariance matrix. The linkage criterion determines the distance between sets of observations. For this study, the Ward's criterion was used, which implies the decrease in variance for the cluster being merged.( 27 ) In other words, the Ward's minimum variance criterion minimizes the total within-cluster variance. The implementation of this method implies to find, at each step, the pair of clusters leading to minimum increase in total within-cluster variance after merging. Gaussian mixture model Gaussian mixture models (GMM) are often used for data clustering and they represent a probabilistic model that assumes that all the data points are generated from a mixture of a finite number of Gaussian distributions with unknown parameters. One can think of mixture models as generalizing K-means clustering to incorporate information about the covariance structure of the data as well as the centres of the latent Gaussians. Moreover, the GMM clustering can accommodate clusters that have different sizes and correlation structures within them. Because of this, the GMM clustering can, in some cases, be more appropriate to use than, e.g. afore demonstrated K-means clustering. Like most clustering methods, analysts must specify the number of desired clusters before fitting the model. The number of clusters specifies the number of components in the GMM.( 29 ) For the GMMs, it is best practice to also consider the Component covariance structure. Analysts can specify diagonal or full covariance matrices, or whether all components have the same covariance matrix. The diagonal covariance structure was chosen for this study( 30 ) ,(31), (32) . Conclusion 3 Data analytics: European Wheel of Competitiveness 35 This article presents different multivariate statistical analysis on indicators of the European Wheel of Competitiveness where the time horizon for the analysis covers the period 2000-2014. First, some widely known or strongly suspected economic relationships between these indicators were confirmed. This first result came in contradiction with the initial hypothesis, that each of proposed indicators brings some unique information regarding competitiveness. For instance, a strong positive correlation was found between indicator 4: Gross domestic expenditure on R&D and indicator 10: R&D expenditure in the business sector. In other words, the two indicators bring similar competitiveness information. Moreover, the associations between indicator 4 and indicator 10, confronted with other indicators, were significant too. With respect to the results, it was decided to explore the partial correlations analysis between the aforementioned indicators with the rest of listed indicators. Interestingly, the results obtained with partial correlation analysis, indicated that the most of the previously captured correlation actually comes from the Gross domestic expenditure on R&D (indicator 4). More precisely, the correlation becomes weaker or insignificant in almost all cases when performing the partial correlation controlling it for indicator 4. Associated with the aforementioned findings and other substantial empirical analysis, this indicator was not considered for the latter analysis. In the same line, the correlation analysis showed that indicator 34: Control of corruption could be also removed from the set of the European Wheel of Competitiveness indicators, since is highly correlated with the indicator 33: Government effectiveness and its information is included in the information provided by the Government effectiveness. This analysis was followed by the cross-correlation analysis exploring the time series correlations and showed that the association between the same pair of indicators, can diverse across observed countries and it can be different for the full sample of the EU-28 Member States. Those results provided the idea of countries clustering, performed afterwards. With respect to aforementioned findings, analysis regarding countries clustering suggested that each obtained group of the EU-28 Member States develops in a similar way in terms of competiveness and that Luxembourg stands out as being very different compared to the other countries. Given the variety of indicators included in this analysis, an important hypothesis explored in this article was to show a possible redundancy between indicators and possible explanatory power. Within this context, it seemed logic to examine the reduction of dimensionality by using the Principal Component Analysis. This statistical analysis tested the initial assumption that the largest principal components will be sufficient to explain the variability in the observed dataset. The results, obtained with the Principal Component analysis, for each group of countries and then for all countries, showed that it would be sufficient to explain the substantial amount of the variability (around 75%) by using only two principal components. Although the performed analysis did not deliver strong evidence for the existence of latent constructs, it did show that the main principal components contain some interesting groups of indicators. Conclusions

Conclusion 3 Data analytics: European Wheel of Competitiveness 36 In addition, another aim of the study was to detect some possible patterns emerged from analysing the available set of indicators: the indicators grouping. All analysis showed that indicators, either as a component of one linear combination or as a member of one group, can be classified into 4 groups. It is also noteworthy the fact that indicator 29: Real GDP per capita stands out as being very different, insofar as it forms its own cluster. Initially, the K-means cluster analysis (pre-specifying 5 groups) was conducted. Even though providing some interesting results, this first analysis was leading to various conclusions, difficult to interpret, when it comes to indicators grouping. Taking into account these preliminary findings, performed with K-means algorithm, it was remarked that, for each country, results have more sense and provide some interesting findings. The initial number of clusters, equal to five, was not the most appropriate and these findings were concluded with four clusters. Consequently, it was of interest to test a more general approach, using the amount of available data for all countries and see if these first results are confirmed. The following two approaches - hierarchical agglomerative clustering and Gaussian mixture distribution, confirmed that similar patterns are emerging and completed the general view on the available data. The number of indicators clusters was calculated by using two statistical criterions: AIC (Akaike Information Criterion) and BIC (Bayesian Information Criterion). Associated with the above presented results, it can be concluded that the correlation between many indicators, after removing the effect of indicator 4, is insignificant or small. Moreover, indicators can be classified into 4 groups of different sizes but with the interesting contents. In addition, analysis showed the existence of homogeneous groups of EU-28 Member States which develop in a similar way in terms of competitiveness. All of this suggests that, despite the fact that indicators 4 and 34 could be removed from the set and that some of data were missing when analysis was conducted, the chosen set of the EWoC indicators is adequate for the analysis of competitiveness.

This study realizes a quality control of the design of the European Wheel of Competitiveness (EWoC) by means of statistical analysis. Results disregard the existence of redundant indicators and confirm that they present different aspects of competitiveness that are not just explained just by the Gross Domestic Product per capita. The paper also identifies country-clusters across the EU-28 Member States and groups of indicators. A cross-correlation analysis of the time series was also performed to test how countries react differently to similar economic changes.
